title: Mum’s eye popped as she dried her face after having shower
text:
Warning: Graphic images

Claire Willis was on the first day of her holiday when her eye popped after she got out the shower (Picture: SWNS)

A mum had to have most of her eye removed after she popped her cornea while drying her face.

Claire Willis said she has now quit her job at a school because she does not want to scare the children.

The cleaner had just got out the shower when she felt a ‘pop’ as she patted her eye with a towel.

She said suddenly her vision went blurry and she was worried her eyeball had actually fallen out of the socket.

The incident happened during a holiday in Turkey and Claire and her husband Tim rushed straight to a local hospital.

Medics told the mum-of-two she had perforated her cornea and needed to fly home immediately.

Unfortunately an infection set in during the flight and doctors were eventually forced to remove a large part of her right eye.

Claire Willis, 45, with her eye patch while she waits more a false eye to be fitted (Picture: SWNS)

Claire Willis pictured before her eyeball had to be amputated (Picture: SWNS)

Claire, 45, recalled tragedy struck during the first day of their trip in July as she and her husband were getting ready to meet friends.

She said: ‘I was drying myself in the bathroom when I just felt this pop in my eye, followed by extreme blurry vision and an excruciating amount of pain.

‘I thought my eyeball had actually popped out of my socket, that’s how painful it was.

‘I raced to the mirror and I couldn’t see any blood or anything – it just looked red and sore and everything was blurry.

‘Tim rushed me to a local hospital and a doctor told me that I had perforated my cornea and that I needed to go back to the UK.’

A recent photo of Claire Willis after the operation with her husband Timothy (Picture: SWNS)

A mum had to have her eye amputated after she popped her cornea while drying her face on holiday (Picture: SWNS)

Within hours the couple were on the next flight home with Thomas Cook and the eye was bandaged over.

Claire, from Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, said she was ‘heartbroken’ at having to cut short the trip but knew it was for the best.

During the flight, her eye became infected and fused itself shut.

Doctors in the UK had to clamp her eyelids open to get a look at her eyeball, which by this point had turned completely yellow.

Claire spent the next nine days in hospital as doctors tried to fight the infection.

However, it failed and doctors said they would have to amputate the eye.

Claire Willis with her infected eye (Picture: SWNS)

Claire recalled: ‘Although I was devastated at the idea, I was in so much pain that I knew it needed to be done.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘There was no saving my sight but the surgeon decided to perform a partial removal of my eyeball rather than a full one.

‘He removed the middle of my eye – the retina and cornea – and fitted a cosmetic shell over the lens of my eye.’

Claire is now adjusting to life after the surgery at the Royal Stoke University Hospital.

She added: ‘After the bandages came off, I had to cope with how I looked and the reality hit me.

‘I looked like an extra from The Walking Dead, and I even left my cleaning job at a school because of how it looked – I didn’t want to scare the kiddies.

‘I was having anxiety issues in public, which really isn’t like me.

‘I never hid my eye though. I didn’t wear sunglasses, I’ve just worn my everyday glasses and I know it’s not forever, it’s only until the prosthetic eye is fitted.’

Claire Willis, 45, felt her eye pop during a holiday to Turkey (Picture: SWNS)

Claire needs to wait until her socket has fully recovered before a false eye can be fitted.

She has returned to one of her cleaning jobs but made the tough decision to leave the school.

The family rebooked their flights back to Turkey with Thomas Cook to enjoy another holiday.

But just five days before they were scheduled to leave, the company collapsed.

The family is now searching for another holiday and hope it will be third time lucky.

Advertisement

Claire added: ‘It was just yet another thing to go wrong, but I’m trying to stay positive and we’re looking for another holiday deal before the year is over.’

An ophthalmologist from Royal Stoke University Hospital said: ‘This lady had particular circumstances that led to a thinner than normal cornea in her case.’
